messages.subject: Re: Masahisa
messages.msgSnippet: How encouraging that the noticeboard has several members who are not blindly prejudiced against Namban tsuba as a group, even if many of these are lacking in
messages.messageBody:
How encouraging that the noticeboard has several members who are not
blindly prejudiced against Namban tsuba as a group, even if many of
these are lacking in both design and execution. I remember my
distress some years ago when, upon being informed of my research on
the group, a senior member of the To-ken scene in GB replied Oh Dear,
but he supposed that somebody had to do it!

The tsuba that Ron describes as being 'made in two pieces' is
probably one of many tsuba which were made in the mid-C19 for sale to
foreigners in Nagasaki. These were made in two non-contiguous halves
that, when joined together gave the impression of undercutting. In
the better of these they were joined by a mimi; in the others they
were simply soldered together.

The Hozon Namban tsuba posted by Richard is very nice. The gold
sleeves that he comments upon appear to be inserts intended to tidy
up the irregularities in the design left by the later addition (or
should I say subtraction) of the ryo-hitsu.

Please keep them coming.

Regards, John L.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <swords@...>

back. That one appeared to be made in two pieces and the "sides"
somehow "welded" together. Never came across another like it since
that time.
>
> Namban are really interesting tsuba and I think they just got a bad
rap years ago because of so many more "common" ones being found. You
see some very nice namban work turn up on Japanese sites and when in
Tokyo in October, I saw several very nice examples -- high priced
examples, I might add. As with all kodogu, you have lots of average
quality stuff, some average-good and then the lesser found great
quality works. It's what makes this study so interesting!
>
> Ron
> STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Masahisa
messages.msgSnippet: I too would be interested in see that. I recently purchased a Namban tsub awhile in Japan that has Hozon kanteisho and is quite nice. Another twist on this is
messages.messageBody:
I too would be interested in see that. I recently purchased a Namban
tsub awhile in Japan that has Hozon kanteisho and is quite nice. Another
twist on this is that Namban tsuba are quite well thought of in Japan,
it is the west that seems to have a lower opinion of them. Perhaps as
they do not come off as quite Japanese on initial study.

http://www.nihontokanjipages.com/personal/tsuba_collection/namban.html
<http://www.nihontokanjipages.com/personal/tsuba_collection/namban.html>

Richard Turner


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Masahisa
messages.msgSnippet: Dear John - Well you tweeked the ego button...will post a photo or two of that nice namban early-on this week. May dig out another uniquely structured namban
messages.messageBody:
Dear John -

Well you tweeked the ego button...will post a photo or two of that nice namban early-on this week. May dig out another uniquely structured namban that I featured in an old JSS/US article years back. That one appeared to be made in two pieces and the "sides" somehow "welded" together. Never came across another like it since that time.

Namban are really interesting tsuba and I think they just got a bad rap years ago because of so many more "common" ones being found. You see some very nice namban work turn up on Japanese sites and when in Tokyo in October, I saw several very nice examples -- high priced examples, I might add. As with all kodogu, you have lots of average quality stuff, some average-good and then the lesser found great quality works. It's what makes this study so interesting!

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Dr John P Lissenden
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, December 03, 2006 4:20 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Masahisa


Dear Rick

Not wishing to be 'picky', I tend to believe that the mistaken
tendency to discount Namban tsuba is based upon their general poor
quality of design and production rather than upon the fact that they
are cast. In an attempt to salvage the reputation of this group
perhaps, if you ask him nicely, Ron Hartman will send you an image of
his Tokubetsu Hozon Namban tsuba?

Regards, John L.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "nihontochicken" <rick@...>
wrote:
>
> Nothing of import to add, really. I would tend to think that were
> Namban tsuba to have been in fact lost wax cast, this would help
> explain their general value discount as compared to most similar
> hand-chiseled pieces.
>
> NC
>
> P.S. - BTW, an email to my personal account on this topic was halted
> by my mail server as "spam" and I don't know how to resurrect it, so
> if there was anything unique in it, please post it to this board.
Thx.
>

messages.subject: Re: Masahisa
messages.msgSnippet: Nothing of import to add, really.  I would tend to think that were Namban tsuba to have been in fact lost wax cast, this would help explain their general value
messages.messageBody:
Nothing of import to add, really. I would tend to think that were
Namban tsuba to have been in fact lost wax cast, this would help
explain their general value discount as compared to most similar
hand-chiseled pieces.

NC

P.S. - BTW, an email to my personal account on this topic was halted
by my mail server as "spam" and I don't know how to resurrect it, so
if there was anything unique in it, please post it to this board. Thx.

messages.subject: Re: Masahisa
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Rick You ask for evidence that the lost wax method of casting was known to the Japanese and you are, of course, quite correct in your assertion that the
messages.messageBody:
Dear Rick

You ask for evidence that the 'lost wax' method of casting was known to
the Japanese and you are, of course, quite correct in your assertion
that the typical Namban tsuba could only have been cast by using this
tecnique. Evidence exists in Japan of the extensive use of both
the 'closed form' and the 'lost form' methods of casting - the former
being known in China as early as the Zhou dynasty (1122-249 BC) and the
latter being introduced there 'relatively late'.

Many Japanese artefacts could only have been produced by the use of
this tecnique, and kagami are but one example of this. The detail of
many cast objects, especially in bronze, could not have been acheived
any other way.

Thus my belif in the casting of Namban tsuba presumes the use of
a 'lost form' method. The naked-eye evidence of casting; the knowledge
that this form as casting was widely known in Japan; and the acceptance
that no other contemporanerous method of casting could have produced
these artefacts seem to support this presumption.

I would be interested to hear your further comments.

Regards, John L.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "nihontochicken" <rick@...> wrote:
>
> --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Dr John P Lissenden"
> <docliss@> wrote:
> > I am personally convinced that the vast majority of Namban
> > tsuba are cast and the poor quality of many of these makes this very
> > easy to detect with the use, simply, of a bright light and x30
> > magnification.
>
> While the "straight through" pierced tsuba may have been made via a
> two piece mold, the 3-D "crossover vine" type Namban tsuba, if cast,
> could only have been done so by a lost wax or similar method, not by a
> "take apart" mold. Is there evidence that the Japanese used something
> like the lost wax method for casting Namban tsuba?
>
> NC
>

messages.subject: Re: Masahisa
messages.msgSnippet: ... While the straight through pierced tsuba may have been made via a two piece mold, the 3-D crossover vine type Namban tsuba, if cast, could only have
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Dr John P Lissenden"
<docliss@...> wrote:
> I am personally convinced that the vast majority of Namban
> tsuba are cast and the poor quality of many of these makes this very
> easy to detect with the use, simply, of a bright light and x30
> magnification.

While the "straight through" pierced tsuba may have been made via a
two piece mold, the 3-D "crossover vine" type Namban tsuba, if cast,
could only have been done so by a lost wax or similar method, not by a
"take apart" mold. Is there evidence that the Japanese used something
like the lost wax method for casting Namban tsuba?

NC

messages.subject: Re: Masahisa
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Elliott Haynes lists no fewer than 17 artists using those kanji, but I agree that Ito Masahisa (H.04022.0), working in Bushu ca 1700, may be your best
messages.messageBody:
Dear Elliott

Haynes lists no fewer than 17 artists using those kanji, but I agree
that Ito Masahisa (H.04022.0), working in Bushu ca 1700, may be your
best bet. Happy hunting.

Regards, John L.

messages.messageBody:
Dr. John,

Thank you very much. I will certainly save a copy of this knowledge
for my personnal use.

I believe this tsuba was made by Ito Masahisa, not Shoami Masahisa. I
need to re-study the Ito school.

Thanks again,

Elliott

messages.subject: Re: Masahisa
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Elliott Your general question re the use of casting tecniques for the production of tsuba, although probably asked in all innocence, opens a whole can of
messages.messageBody:
Dear Elliott

Your general question re the use of casting tecniques for the
production of tsuba, although probably asked in all innocence, opens a
whole 'can of worms'.

There is no doubt that casting was accepted as a skilled form of
metalworking and was used to produce cast bronze vessels and mirrors,
and iron kettles. Indeed, a cast kagami is one of the Three Sacred
Regalia of Japan. Kagami-shi tsuba, supposedly made in the pre-Edo
period by mirror makers, may also be of extremely high quality and it
is not illogical to suppose that many soft-metal tsuba may have
initially been cast.

But the casting of iron tsuba is, for some reason, very frowned upon by
collectors. I am personally convinced that the vast majority of Namban
tsuba are cast and the poor quality of many of these makes this very
easy to detect with the use, simply, of a bright light and x30
magnification. The ease with which casting can be identified clearly
depends upon the amount of hand finishing which was utilised afterwards.

Many people will justify the casting of Manban tsuba as being expected
because of their poor quality, but I believe that casting may have been
used far more generally than is accepted. It should be a simple matter
to confirm this, but such examinations would need to be carried out on
tsuba of accepted high quality in order to avoid the a priori excuse
of 'poor quality'.

White cast iron is not a suitable metal for casting, but the
carburisation of grey cast iron to produce a malleable cast iron,
which is ideal for casting small artefacts such as tsuba, is a process
that has been known in Japan for several hundred years.

As to whether the tsuba illustrated in your photo album is cast or not,
I would hesitate to offer a firm opinion without a hands-on
examination. But my first impression is the absence of any clean,
sharp chisel-work - I have my suspicions!

Regards, John L.

messages.subject: Masahisa
messages.msgSnippet: My question today is......... Did Tsuba makers in the Edo period ever cast their work? I have a Tsuba that appears to have cast marks. I was told that it
messages.messageBody:
My question today is......... Did Tsuba makers in the Edo period
ever 'cast' their work?
I have a Tsuba that appears to have 'cast' marks. I was told that it
was made in Edo period, the mei is Masahisa, the design of clouds was
carved or engraved, and in oval shape. I was told it was 'authentic'. I
have also been told that this tsuba is a cast reproduction.
I am prepared for any answer I receive. This is all part of my on-going
education. Is this one of the Shiiremono(sp) tourist tsubas?

The pictures have been added to my album - numbers 28, 29, 30, & 31.

As always, Thank you again.

Elliott
